stem: A 38-year-old male patient with a T6 spinal cord injury is admitted to the ICU. The patient reports a severe headache and blurred vision. Based on the data provided, which of the following interventions should the nurse prioritize?

itemContext.sbar: S: John Smith, a 38-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, was admitted to the ICU at 06:00 today. At 09:30, the patient reported a severe headache and blurred vision. The patient rates the headache as an 8/10 at 10:00. B: He sustained the spinal cord injury in a motor vehicle accident 5 years ago and typically manages at home with assistance for daily activities. A: Current vital signs at 10:00 are: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 55 bpm, RR 20 breaths per minute, and SpO2 98% on room air. The skin is flushed above the level of the injury and pale and cool below. The patient is also diaphoretic. Catheterized urine output has been 30 mL over the last hour. The patient reports a bowel movement two days ago. O: I suspect the patient is experiencing autonomic dysreflexia. This requires immediate nursing interventions and notification of the healthcare provider STAT due to the risk of stroke or seizure.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.2 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, HCO3: 24 mEq/L, BUN: 18 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL, WBC: 8.0 x 10^3/uL, Hgb: 14 g/dL, Hct: 42%, Glucose: 95 mg/dL, Urine Culture: pending

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Scheduled: Docusate 100mg PO daily, Multivitamin PO daily. PRN: Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4h PRN for headache, Hydralazine 10mg IV PRN for SBP > 180 mmHg. Last dose Acetaminophen given at 06:00.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
09:00: BP 190/100 mmHg, HR 60 bpm, RR 20, SpO2 98% on room air.
09:30: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 55 bpm, RR 20, SpO2 98% on room air. Patient reports headache and blurred vision.
10:00: BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 55 bpm, RR 20, SpO2 98% on room air. Patient states headache is 8/10.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct:
Assess for bladder distension: Bladder distension is a common trigger for autonomic dysreflexia. Catheter patency should be checked and any kinks resolved.
Elevate the head of the bed: Elevating the head of the bed to a high-Fowler's position helps to lower the blood pressure by promoting venous pooling.
Monitor blood pressure every 5 minutes: Frequent monitoring is crucial to assess the effectiveness of interventions and to detect further changes in blood pressure.
Loosen any restrictive clothing: Restrictive clothing can exacerbate the hypertensive response. Removing or loosening clothing can help to reduce the stimulus.
Check for bowel impaction: Bowel impaction is another common trigger. A digital rectal examination should be performed to assess for impaction after bladder issues are ruled out.
rationale.incorrect:
Administer acetaminophen 650mg PO: While the patient reports a headache, the priority is to address the underlying cause of the autonomic dysreflexia. Acetaminophen will not resolve the hypertension.
Increase IV fluid rate: Increasing IV fluids may worsen the hypertension. Fluid overload is contraindicated in this situation.
clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention to prevent severe complications such as stroke or seizures.
The most common triggers of autonomic dysreflexia are bladder distension and bowel impaction.
Always address the most common triggers first before considering less likely causes.

questionTrap.trap: The question trap lies in focusing solely on the headache without recognizing it as a symptom of the more serious condition of autonomic dysreflexia. Selecting interventions aimed only at pain relief will delay treatment of the underlying cause and can lead to significant patient harm.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the underlying pathophysiology and the interconnectedness of the symptoms. Recognize that the severe headache, blurred vision, and elevated blood pressure in a patient with a T6 spinal cord injury strongly suggest autonomic dysreflexia, necessitating interventions to address the hypertensive crisis.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion:
S - Search for the cause
I - Initiate monitoring (BP, HR)
T - Treat the cause (bladder, bowel)
U - Upright position
P - Pharmaceutical intervention if needed
